CODIFIED ORDINANCES
OF THE CITY OF DAVISON, MICHIGAN

CERTIFICATION
   We, Stacey Kalisz, Mayor, and Andrea L. Schroeder, City Clerk, hereby
certify that the general and permanent legislation of the City of Davison,
Michigan, as revised, arranged, compiled, numbered, codified and printed
herewith in component codes, is correctly set forth and constitutes the
Codified Ordinances of the City of Davison, Michigan, 1983, complete to
December 31, 2024.
                           /s/   Stacey Kalisz
                              Mayor Pro Tem
                           /s/   Andrea L. Schroeder
                              City Clerk

COMPARATIVE SECTION TABLE
EDITOR'S NOTE: Source material for the 1983 Codified Ordinances of Davison was
ordinances or resolutions enacted by Council or new matter ordained by the
Adopting Ordinance. Sections and subsections of the 1983 Codified Ordinances
without a history or with the words Adopting Ordinance at the end thereof are
new matter ordained by the Adopting Ordinance. In the following table the
disposition of all source material in the 1983 Davison Codified ordinances in
indicated.

TABLES OF SPECIAL ORDINANCES
EXPLANATION OF TABLES OF SPECIAL ORDINANCES
   The Codified Ordinances of Davison comprises all ordinances of a general and
permanent nature. The provisions of such general and permanent ordinances are
set forth in full in the Codified Ordinances.
   References must be made frequently to many special ordinances, particularly
those relating to property, such as easements, vacations, dedications,
acquisitions, disposals, leases, etc. In the following Tables A through I, all
such ordinances are listed. These Tables list ordinances chronologically by
subject and include both a citation to and brief description of each ordinance.
TABLE A   -   Franchises
TABLE B   -   Easements
TABLE C   -   Vacating of Streets and Alleys
TABLE D   -   Dedication and Plat Approval
TABLE E   -   Acquisition and Disposal of Real Property
TABLE F   -   Lease of Real Property
TABLE G   -   Street Grade Levels and Change of Street Name
TABLE H   -   Annexation and Detachment of Territory
TABLE I   -   Zoning Map Changes

CHARTER OF THE CITY OF DAVISON, MICHIGAN
EDITOR'S NOTE: The original Charter of the City of Davison was adopted on March
13, 1939. The present Charter of the City of Davison, codified herein, was
adopted by the voters at a special election held on August 3, 1999, and became
effective September 1, 1999. Dates appearing in parentheses following an
article or section heading in the Table of Contents, and following a section in
the text, indicate that the article or section was enacted, amended or repealed
on the date given.

PREAMBLE
We the people of the City of Davison, pursuant to authority granted by the
Constitution and laws of the State of Michigan, in order to obtain the benefits
of local home rule, to encourage more direct and efficient methods in the
transaction of our Municipal affairs, and otherwise to promote our common
welfare, do ordain and establish this Charter for the City of Davison.
ARTICLE I
INCORPORATION; ORGANIZATION AND POWERS
Section 1.1. Corporation and Boundaries.
   The municipal corporation now existing and known as the City of Davison
shall continue as a body corporate and shall include the territory constituting
the City of Davison on the effective date of this Charter together with any
territory which may be annexed to it as provided by State law. The name, "City
of Davison," shall be referred to as the "City" following in this document.
Section 1.2. Form of Government.
   The municipal form of government provided for in the Charter shall be the
Council-Manager form of government. All powers of the City shall be vested in
an elective council pursuant to the provisions of this Charter and the
Constitution and laws of the State of Michigan.
Section 1.3. Powers.
   The City shall be vested with any and all powers which cities are, or
hereafter may be, permitted to exercise or to provide for in their charters
including all powers granted to home rule cities. All vested powers shall be as
full and complete as though those powers were specifically incorporated into
and provided for in this Charter subject to the Constitution and the laws of
the State of Michigan. Any enumeration of particular powers in this Charter
shall in no case be held to be exclusive.
ARTICLE II
THE CITY CHARTER
Section 2.1. Penalty.
   All violations of any part of this Charter by officers of the City shall be
considered misconduct in office. All offenses by officers of the City declared
by this Charter to constitute misconduct in office shall be punishable by a
fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500) or by imprisonment for a period
not exceeding ninety (90) days, or both in the discretion of the court.
Section 2.2. Effect of Illegality of Any Part of Charter.
   Should any provision or section, or portion thereof, of this Charter be held
by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, illegal or
unconstitutional, such holding shall not be construed as affecting the validity
of this Charter as a whole or of any remaining portion of such provision or
section.
Section 2.3. Amendments.
   This Charter may be amended at any time in the manner provided in Act No.
279 of the Public Acts of 1909, as amended. An amendment shall be approved if
it receives a majority of the electors voting on the amendment. Should two (2)
or more amendments, adopted at the same election, have conflicting provisions,
the one receiving the highest vote shall prevail as to those provisions.
Section 2.4. Familiarity of City Officials With the City Charter.
   Persons serving on the City Council, all boards, all commissions, City
administrators, the City Attorney, the City Manager, all appointed officials,
all elected officials, and all department heads are required to read the City
Charter and file a letter with the City Clerk indicating that he or she has
read the City Charter.
ARTICLE III
INTERGOVERNMENTAL AGREEMENTS
Section 3.1. Intergovernmental Agreements.
   Where it is advantageous, the City may enter into Intergovernmental
Agreements with other political entities in a manner consistent with State law.
The Council shall assure that:
      A.   Financial obligations incurred by the City under any such agreements
are proportional to the benefits gained.
      B.   The City Manager, Treasurer, and Clerk remain employees of the City
exclusively, and these officers shall not be employed by any other governmental
unit, or inter-governmental unit.
      C.   Regular written reports are received from the operating entities of
the Intergovernmental Agreements and the Council evaluates the City's
participation in each agreement at least annually to determine if they are
meeting goals and objectives.
ARTICLE IV
ELECTIONS
Section 4.1. Election Districts.
   The City shall constitute one (1) ward, which shall be divided into such
number of election districts as may be required by State law. The election
districts within the City shall have clearly established boundaries defined by
ordinance in accordance with State law.
Section 4.2. Qualifications of Electors.
   Each person who has the constitutional qualifications of an elector in the
State of Michigan or who will have such qualifications at the next regular or
special election shall be entitled to register as an elector of the City of
Davison in the voting district in which that person resides.
Section 4.3. Election Procedure.
   The general election laws of the State shall apply to and control, as near
as may be, all procedure relating to registration and City elections, except as
otherwise provided by this Charter.
Section 4.4. Regular Elections.
   A non-partisan regular City election shall be held for the election of City
officers during the general election which shall be held on the Tuesday
following the first Monday in November in each even-numbered year.
(Amended 11-7-06; Res. 2014-27. Passed 11-10-14.)
Section 4.5. Special Elections.
   Special elections shall be held when called by resolution of the City
Council or as provided by State law. The number of special elections shall be
determined by State law as provided in the Home Rule Cities Act.
Section 4.6. Notice of Elections.
   Notice of all elections including time, place, the offices, and questions to
be voted on shall be given by the City Clerk as provided by State election laws
governing such notices.
Section 4.7. Voting Hours.
   The polls of all elections shall be opened as provided by State laws.
Section 4.8. Nominating Petitions.
   Persons desiring to qualify as candidates for any elective office under this
Charter shall file with the City Clerk an Affidavit of Identity as required by
State law and a petition therefor signed by not less than fifty (50) registered
electors of the City not later than 4:00 p.m. on the first Tuesday after the
first Monday in August of any even-numbered year. Blank forms as required by
State law for State and County officers shall be furnished by the Clerk. The
Clerk shall publish notice of the last filing day for nominating petitions in
the time period from the twenty-first (21st) day through the seventh (7th) day
preceding the last filing day. If a qualified and registered voter signs
nominating petitions for a greater number of candidates for public office than
the number of persons to be elected thereto, his signatures, if they bear the
same date, shall not be counted upon any petition, and if they bear different
dates, shall be counted in the order of their priority of date for only so many
candidates as there are persons to be elected.
(Amended 11-7-06; Res. 2014-27. Passed 11-10-14.)
Section 4.9. Approval of Petitions.
   The Clerk shall accept for filing only nominating petitions on official
blanks containing the required number of signatures for candidates having those
qualifications required for elective City officers by this Charter. Petitions
may be submitted by a person other than the candidate only when accompanied by
an Affidavit of Identity as required by State law. The Clerk shall determine
the sufficiency of the signatures on each petition and shall notify the
candidate in writing within five (5) days if any petition does not contain the
required number of legal signatures.
   Each petition which is found by the Clerk to contain the required number of
signatures of registered electors for candidates shall be marked "Qualified",
with the date thereof. The Clerk shall notify in writing the candidate whose
name appears on each petition.
Section 4.10. Public Inspection of Petitions.
   All nominating petitions shall be open to public inspection after being
filed in the office of the Clerk.
Section 4.11. Nominations to Fill Vacancy in Elective Office.
   Whenever it shall be necessary at any City election to elect an officer to
fill a vacancy for an unexpired term, such fact shall be stated in the
petitions filed for the purpose of nominating candidates to fill such vacancy.
Section 4.12. Names on Ballots.
   The form of the ballot used in any City election shall conform as nearly as
possible to that prescribed by the general laws of the State except that no
party designation or emblem shall appear upon any City ballot.
Section 4.13. Election Commission.
   The Election Commission shall consist of the Clerk, the Mayor, and one other
elective or appointive City officer as the Council may designate. The Clerk
shall be Chairman. The Commission shall have charge of all activities and
duties required of it by State law and this Charter relating to the conduct of
elections in the City. The compensation of election personnel shall be
determined in advance by the Commission and shall be a fixed amount for each
election, however, such compensation shall not exceed the amount appropriated
for elections in the budget unless such increase shall first have been approved
by the Council as are other increases in appropriations for any department or
function.
Section 4.14. Canvass of Votes.
   The canvasing of votes shall be accomplished by the Genesee County Board of
Canvassers or as otherwise prescribed by State law.
Section 4.15. Tie Vote.
   If at any election there shall be no choice between candidates because two
(2) or more received an equal number of votes, then the candidates shall appear
for a determination of the election at a place and by a method provided for by
State law.
Section 4.16. Recount.
   A recount of the votes cast at any City election for any office or upon any
proposition may be had in accordance with the general election laws of the
State.
ARTICLE V
ELECTIVE OFFICERS OF THE CITY; GENERAL
Section 5.1. Elective Officers.
   There shall be elected at large in the City of Davison a Mayor and six (6)
Council members in the manner and at such times as is prescribed in this
Charter. The Mayor shall be a member of the Council.
Section 5.2. Qualifications.
   No person shall be eligible for any elective office who is a defaulter to
the City or to any other political subdivision of the State and unless he is a
duly registered elector in the City and has been a resident of the City for one
(1) year immediately prior to the election at which he is a candidate for
office. All votes for or appointment of any person contrary to the provisions
of this section shall be void.
Section 5.3. Term of Office.
   The Mayor shall be elected in even-numbered years and shall hold office for
a term of four (4) years. For Council member terms beginning in 2006, each
Council member shall hold office for a term of three (3) years. For Council
member terms beginning in 2007, and for each Council member term thereafter,
each Council member shall hold office for a term of four (4) years. The Mayor’s
and Council members’ terms shall begin on the second Monday following the
regular City election at which they were elected. Council member terms will be
alternating with three (3) Council members elected every other even-numbered
year.
(Amended 11-7-06; Res. 2014-27. Passed 11-10-14.)
Section 5.4. Oath of Office.
   Each elective officer of the City shall before entering upon the duties of
his office take and subscribe to the oath of office prescribed by the State
Constitution for officers of the State. The oath shall be filed and kept in the
office of the Clerk.
Section 5.5. Notice of Election and Qualifying to Serve.
   Written notice by the Clerk of the election of any officer of the City and
of the requirement of any official bond to be given by any such officer shall
be given him within five (5) days after the canvass of the vote by which he was
elected. Any elected officer shall be deemed refusing to serve and the office
shall be deemed vacant if within ten (10) days from the date of notice, such
officer shall not take, subscribe and file with the Clerk the oath of office,
or shall not execute and file with the Clerk the required bond. However, the
Council may for good cause extend the time in which such officer may qualify to
serve.
Section 5.6. Surety Bonds.
   Any elected officer receiving or disbursing City funds shall be bonded.
Also, any elected City officer may be required to give a bond for the faithful
performance of the duties of his office. All bonds shall be approved by the
Council in such sums as it shall determine. All official bonds shall be
corporate surety bonds and their premiums shall be paid by the City. All
official bonds shall be filed with the Clerk.
Section 5.7. Vacancy Defined.
   In addition to other provisions of this Charter, a vacancy shall be deemed
to exist in any elective office when any such officer dies, resigns, is removed
from office, moves from the City, is convicted of a felony or of misconduct in
office under this Charter, is judicially declared to be mentally incompetent,
or misses either four (4) consecutive regular Council meetings or twenty-five
(25) percent of all regular Council meetings in any calendar year. The Clerk
shall be responsible to maintain the record of absences, and shall notify the
Council immediately when a vacancy due to absences has occurred.
Section 5.8. Vacancies.
   Any vacancy occurring in any elective office shall be filled by the Council
within forty-five (45) days after such vacancy shall have occurred except as
otherwise provided in this Charter. The appointee shall serve until the second
Monday following the next regular City election. If the term of office filled
by appointment extends beyond the second Monday following the next regular City
election, the vacancy shall be filled at that election for the balance of the
term.
   If after forty-five (45) days the vacancy shall not have been filled, a
special election shall be held to fill the vacancy for the balance of the term.
ARTICLE VI
ELECTIVE OFFICERS OF THE CITY; DUTIES
Section 6.1. The Council.
   The government of the City and all its powers shall be vested in the
Council. The Council shall exercise for the City all the Municipal powers
possessed by the City for the management and control of Municipal property and
for the administration of the Municipal government whether or not such powers
are expressly enumerated in this Charter. It shall make all necessary and
proper laws for executing the powers granted to the City by this Charter and
the Constitution and general laws of the State.
Section 6.2. Mayor.
   The Mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the City, shall be a
member of the Council and shall preside at all its meetings and may speak and
vote in such meetings as any other member of the Council. The Mayor shall be
the official head of the City for ceremonial purposes. The Mayor shall deliver
a "State of the City" address annually at the first Council meeting in March.
In addition to the annual report by the Mayor, a written report will be
available to the public.
Section 6.3. Mayor Pro Tempore.
   At the first meeting of the Council following each regular City election the
Council shall elect one (1) of its members Mayor Pro Tempore to perform the
duties of the Mayor during the absence or disability of the Mayor.
Section 6.4. Compensation.
   The salaries of all elective officers of the City shall continue to be
determined by the Local Officers Compensation Commission as established by City
ordinances numbers 276.01, 276.02, 276.03, 276.04, 276.05 pursuant to State
law.
Section 6.5. Regular Meetings.
   The Council shall meet at the usual place of holding Council meetings, at 7:
30 p.m., Eastern Time, on the second Monday next following each regular City
election, at which session the Mayor and newly elected members of the Council
shall be qualified and assume the duties of their office. Regular meetings
shall be held at least once each month, for the transaction of business, at
such time and place within the City as the Council shall prescribe by
resolution.
Section 6.6. Special Meetings.
   Special meetings may be called by the Clerk on the written request of the
Mayor or any three (3) members of the Council on at least eighteen (18) hours
written notice to each member of the Council served personally or left at the
member's usual place of residence by the City Clerk or the Clerk's designee.
However any special meeting at which all members of the Council are present or
have waived notice in writing, shall be a legal meeting for all purposes,
without such notice.
Section 6.7. Quorum.
   A majority of the members of the Council shall be a quorum for the
transaction of business.
Section 6.8. Rules.
   The Council shall determine its own rules and order of business and shall
keep a journal of all of its proceedings in the English language which shall be
signed by the Mayor and the Clerk. The Council's rules, order of business, and
journal shall be available to the general public for examination.
Section 6.9. Meetings of Council to be Public.
   All regular and special meetings of the Council shall be open to the public,
and the rules of the Council shall provide that the citizens shall have a
reasonable opportunity to be heard on any matter under consideration. All
meetings shall be subject to the Open Meetings Act, being Public Act No. 267 of
1976, as amended, and the Council shall have the right to hold closed sessions
of the Council, as authorized by the act.
Section 6.10. Discipline and Attendance.
   The Council shall be the judge of the election and qualification of its own
members subject to review by the courts in cases of contest. The Council shall
have the authority to enforce orderly conduct at its meetings, and any member
of the Council who engages in disorderly conduct shall be deemed guilty of
misconduct in office. The Council by a majority vote of those present may
require the attendance at any meeting of any appointive officer of the City and
any other employee through the chain of command process.
Section 6.11. Limitations on the Powers of the Council.
   No ordinance or resolution shall be adopted or passed except by the
affirmative vote of at least a majority of the members of the Council. No
office shall be created or abolished, no tax or assessment imposed, no street,
alley or public ground vacated, no real estate or any interest therein sold or
disposed of, no private property taken for public use, no vote of the Council
reconsidered or rescinded at a special meeting, nor any money appropriated
except as otherwise provided in this Charter, unless by the affirmative vote of
at least two-thirds (2/3) of the members of the Council.
Section 6.12. Investigations.
   The Council or any person or committee authorized by it for the purpose
shall have power to inquire into the conduct of any department, office, or
officer of the City and to make investigations as to municipal affairs, and for
that purpose, may subpoena witnesses, administer oaths and compel the
production of books, papers, and other evidence. Failure on the part of any
officer of the City to obey such subpoena or to produce books, papers, or other
evidence as ordered under the provisions of this section shall constitute
misconduct in office. If such failure shall be on the part of any employee of
the City, the same shall constitute a misdemeanor.
ARTICLE VII
APPOINTIVE OFFICERS OF THE CITY; GENERAL
Section 7.1. Statement of Policy.
   It is the policy of this Charter that, except as otherwise provided in this
Charter, all matters relating and pertaining to the administration of the City
government shall be performed by the appointive officers and personnel of the
City. The Council is responsible for the appointment and dismissal of the
appointed officers, but the Council and it's members shall not interfere in the
daily operations of the appointed officers nor in the management of their
employees.
Section 7.2. Appointive Officers.
   The appointive officers of the City shall be a Treasurer, an Assessor, a
Police Chief, a City Attorney, a Board of Review, a City Clerk, and a City
Manager. The Council may create by ordinance such additional offices as it may
deem necessary for the operation of the City government, provided they do not
invade the functions of the foregoing offices, or may combine any such offices
in one or more persons in any manner not inconsistent with the general laws of
the State.
Section 7.3. Appointment and Qualifications.
   The appointive officers of the City shall be appointed to and removed from
office at the pleasure of the Council. Appointees shall be selected with
reference only to their qualifications and fitness for the good of the public
service and without any reference or regard to their religious faith, political
party affiliation, sex, race, or ethnic background. The City Manager, the
Police Chief, the Assessor, the Clerk, and the Treasurer shall be City
residents within eighteen (18) months of the beginning of employment. This
residency requirement shall not apply to those nonresidents holding an
appointive office at the time of the enactment of this Charter.
Section 7.4. Terms of Office.
   All appointive officers shall, except as otherwise provided in this Charter,
hold office until their successors are chosen and qualified.
Section 7.5. Compensation.
   The compensation of the appointive officers shall be fixed by the Council.
Section 7.6. Notice of Appointment.
   Notice of the appointment of any appointive officer shall be given the
officer by the Clerk in writing within five (5) days after the appointment by
the Council.
Section 7.7. Oath of Office.
   Before entering upon the duties of office, every appointive officer shall
take and subscribe to the usual oath of office as provided by the State
Constitution for State officers. The oath shall be filed with the Clerk.
Failure by an officer to take, subscribe, and file with the Clerk the oath of
office within ten (10) days from the date of notice shall be deemed a refusal
to serve, and the office shall be deemed vacant unless the Council shall extend
the time in which such officer may qualify.
Section 7.8. Books, Records and City Property.
   Immediately upon vacation of any City office, the vacating officer shall
surrender to the Council or the Council's designee all books, papers, records,
and other City property which may be in the officer's custody. The failure of
the vacating officer to do so shall constitute a misdemeanor.
Section 7.9. Vacancy Defined.
   In addition to other provisions of this Charter, a vacancy shall be deemed
to exist in any appointive office when any such officer dies, resigns, is
removed from office, moves from the City if residency is required, is convicted
of a felony or of misconduct in office under this Charter, or is judicially
declared to be mentally incompetent.
Section 7.10. Filling Vacancies.
   In the event of a vacancy in any appointive office, the Council shall
appoint another person to hold such office within one hundred eighty (180)
days. However, an acting replacement for any appointive officer must be named
if a vacancy exceeds fifteen (15) days.
ARTICLE VIII
APPOINTIVE OFFICERS OF THE CITY; DUTIES
Section 8.1. City Manager.
   The Council shall appoint a City Manager who shall be responsible to the
Council. The City Manager shall be the administrative head of the government
under the direction and supervision of the Council and shall hold office at the
pleasure of the Council. To be eligible for appointment, a candidate shall
demonstrate appropriate training and experience to successfully discharge the
duties of the position as determined by State law and the City Council. During
the absence or disability of the City Manager or a vacancy in that office, the
Council shall designate as Acting Manager a properly qualified person to
execute the functions of that office until the Manager is again available for
work or a new one is chosen.
Section 8.2. Removal of City Manager.
   The City Manager shall not be removed within thirty (30) days after any
regular City election.
Section 8.3. Functions of the City Manager.
   The City Manager shall plan, organize, and direct the activities of City
departments in accordance with City policy; advise and assist the Council in
conducting its business; perform the purchasing, personnel, and traffic
engineering functions for the City; and perform related work as required.
The functions of the City Manager shall be, but not limited, to:
   1.   Plan, organize and direct activities of City departments in accordance
with City policy.
         a.   Oversee programs directed by department heads and keep informed
on major developments and obstacles and be responsible to the Council for the
efficient administration of all departments of the City government.
         b.   Evaluate performance of employees and assess staffing
requirements in accordance with the City budget. Appoint, promote, and
terminate department heads and other employees as necessary except for
appointive officers.
         c.   Oversee the Treasurer's handling of revenues and investments
throughout the year. Prepare and administer an annual balanced budget which
considers community needs, departmental priorities, and available funds.
         d.   Oversee contract administration ensuring that all terms and
conditions imposed in favor of the City or its inhabitants in any contract or
public utility franchise are faithfully kept and performed.
         e.   Determine priorities for various City departments and communicate
these to appropriate department heads.
         f.   Be responsible to the Council for the proper discharge of all the
just obligations of the City.
   2.   Advise and assist the City Council in conducting its business.
         a.   Attend all regular meetings of the Council and those special
meetings in which the Manager's attendance may be required in the notice,
having the right to participate in discussions but without the right to vote.
         b.   Prepare agenda for City Council meetings and provide background
information necessary to adopt resolutions and ordinances.
         c.   Serve as an ex officio member of all committees of the Council.
         d.   Recommend to the Council for adoption those measures deemed
necessary or expedient.
         e.   Convey matters of community concern to Council members and
suggest issues that should be addressed.
         f.   Conduct study sessions and workshops with City Council members to
convey Staff expertise in certain areas.
         g.   Raise policy questions to the City Council with short and long
range implications for City operations, make recommendations, and provide
alternatives for consideration.
         h.   Prepare special reports for Council and meet with elected
officials as required.
         i.   Provide City Council with a quarterly summary of the City's
financial condition and keep the Council fully advised at all times of the
financial condition and needs of the City.
   3.   Perform the purchasing, personnel, traffic engineering, and other
functions for the City.
         a.   Ensure that all laws and ordinances are enforced and administer
code enforcement activities for the City.
         b.   Manage and supervise all public improvements, works, and
undertakings of the City. Have charge of the construction, repair, maintenance,
cleaning and lighting of streets, sidewalks, bridges, pavements, sewers, and of
all public buildings or other property belonging to the City.
         c.   Communicate City Council policy to the public and media. Act as a
community resource for questions pertaining to policy.
         d.   Prepare plans and specifications. Obtain easements, review
technical data and bids.
         e.   Exercise and perform all administrative functions of the City
that are not imposed by this Charter or any City ordinance upon some other
official.
   4.   Perform other work or duties as may be prescribed by this Charter or as
may be required of the Manager by ordinance or by direction or appointment of
the Council.
Section 8.4. Clerk.
   The Council shall appoint a City Clerk who shall be responsible to the City
Manager and shall hold office at the pleasure of the Council. To be eligible
for appointment, a candidate shall demonstrate appropriate training and
experience to successfully discharge the duties of the position as determined
by State law and the City Council. During the absence or disability of the City
Clerk or a vacancy in that office, the Council shall designate as Acting Clerk
a properly qualified person to execute the functions of that office until the
Clerk is again available for work or a new one is chosen.
Section 8.5. Functions of the City Clerk.
   The Clerk shall perform all duties required of city clerks by State law, the
provisions of this Charter, and the ordinances of the City. The Clerk shall
serve as Clerk to the City Council; oversee the registration of voters and the
holding of elections; and perform related work as required.
The functions of the City Clerk shall be, but not limited, to:
   1.   Serve as Clerk to the City Council.
         a.   Attend Council meetings, take minutes of the meetings.
         b.   Prepare minutes for Council meetings.
         c.   Prepare and edit resolutions, proclamations, and ordinances for
City Council and the City Manager according to a standardized format.
   2.   Oversee the registration of voters and the conduct of local, state, and
federal elections.
         a.   Implement state election laws.
         b.   Publish election notices, issue absentee ballots, and forward
returns to the County Clerk.
   3.   Other related duties.
         a.   Maintain records and files according to a standard filing system
and maintain a proper retention and disposal schedule.
         b.   Administer the City Corporate Seal on request to certify
documents.
         c.   Administer oaths of office and sign official documents including
ordinances and resolutions.
Section 8.6. Treasurer.
   The Council shall appoint a City Treasurer who shall be responsible to the
City Manager and shall hold office at the pleasure of the Council. To be
eligible for appointment, a candidate shall demonstrate appropriate training
and experience to successfully discharge the duties of the position as
determined by State law and the City Council. During the absence or disability
of the City Treasurer or a vacancy in that office, the Council shall designate
as Acting Treasurer some properly qualified person to execute the functions of
that office until the Treasurer is again available for work or a new one is
chosen.
Section 8.7. Functions of the City Treasurer.
   The Treasurer shall be charged with the custody of all public moneys of the
City and shall be responsible for all moneys turned over to the Treasurer by
other City officials or deposited by them in the depository or depositories
designated by the Council. The Treasurer shall keep the accounts of the City
government and shall report to the Council quarterly in the months of March,
June, September, and December. The Treasurer shall pay no money out of the City
Treasury except in a manner as prescribed by State law. All checks shall be
signed by two of the following officers: Clerk, Treasurer, City Manager, or
Mayor. The Treasurer shall further perform such duties as shall be required by
State law, the provisions of this Charter, and by City ordinance.
Section 8.8. Police Chief.
   The Council shall appoint a Police Chief who shall be responsible to the
City Manager and shall hold office at the pleasure of the Council. To be
eligible for appointment, a candidate shall demonstrate appropriate
certification, training, and experience to successfully discharge the duties of
the position as determined by State law and the City Council. During the
absence or disability of the Police Chief or a vacancy in that office, the
Council shall designate as Acting Chief some properly qualified person to
execute the functions of that office until the Chief is again available for
work or a new one is chosen.
Section 8.9. Functions of the Police Chief.
   The Chief shall perform all duties required of police chiefs by State law,
the provisions of this Charter, and the ordinances of the City, and the Chief
shall plan and direct the office and field activities of the City Police
Department, patrol City streets and investigate crime, and perform related work
as required.
Section 8.10. Assessor.
   The Assessor shall be the assessing officer of the City and shall prepare
all of the assessment and tax rolls of the City both general and special. The
Assessor shall perform all the duties and have all the powers required of and
possessed by assessing officers under the general laws of the State.
Section 8.11. Attorney.
   The City Attorney shall be the legal advisor of the Council and of all
officers and departments of the City and shall act as attorney for the City in
all legal proceedings in which the City is interested, and the Attorney shall
prosecute all offenses against the ordinances of the City and the provisions of
this Charter. This Charter recognizes that City business may require more than
one attorney.
Section 8.12. Board of Review.
   The Board of Review shall consist of the Mayor and four (4) electors of the
City appointed by the City Council, who meet the qualifications of this Charter
for officers of the City. No appointed members of the Board may hold another
City office or be City employees during their term of office. Members may be
removed from office by the vote of four (4) members of the City Council. The
term of office for the four (4) appointed members shall be four (4) years, and
no appointed member shall serve more than two (2) consecutive terms. The terms
of office shall be staggered with one member to be appointed each year except
that of the members first appointed, one each shall be appointed for terms of
one (1), two (2), three (3), and four (4) years. The terms shall begin January
1. The Board shall select one of its members to be the chairperson at the first
meeting of each year. The Assessor shall be a non-voting member of the Board
and shall serve as clerk, shall attend all meetings of the Board, and must be
able to present the position of the Assessor's office. The provision that no
member shall serve more that two (2) consecutive terms shall not apply to a
position filled after a vacancy occurs if the remainder of the term for that
position is less than two (2) years nor shall that provision apply to the
shortened terms of the members first appointed under this Charter.
Section 8.13. Other Appointive Officers.
   The powers and duties of all other appointive officers, except as otherwise
provided by State law or this Charter, shall be prescribed by ordinance.
Section 8.14. Fees.
   Except as otherwise provided in this Charter, all fees paid to any
appointive officer in the performance of any duties which may be required under
the ordinances of the City, this Charter, or by State law shall be accounted
for and forthwith deposited upon receipt in a depository designated by the
Council. Failure to do so shall constitute misconduct in office.
ARTICLE IX
RECALL; INITIATIVE AND REFERENDUM
Section 9.1. Recall.
   Any elective officer may be removed from office by the electors in the
manner provided by the general laws of the State of Michigan. A vacancy created
by the recall of any elective officer shall be filled in the manner prescribed
by State law. No person who has been removed from office by recall or who has
resigned from such office while recall proceedings are pending against that
person shall be appointed to any elective City office during the term of office
from which the officer was recalled or resigned or any other City office within
one (1) year after such recall or resignation.
Section 9.2. Initiative and Referendum.
   An ordinance may be initiated by petition. A referendum on an ordinance
which is legislative in nature, enacted by the Council may be had by a petition
filed prior to sixty (60) days subsequent to enactment of the ordinance as
hereinafter provided.
Section 9.3. Petitions.
   An initiatory or a referendary petition shall be signed by one hundred (100)
registered qualified electors of the City prior to the filing of the petition.
Before being circulated for signatures, the form of all such petitions shall be
approved by the City Attorney. No petition need be on one paper but may be on
two (2) or more petition papers. Each signer of a petition shall sign in ink
and shall place after the signature the date and place of residence by street
and number, or by other customary designation, of the signer. Any such petition
shall be filed with the City Clerk who shall within ten (10) days determine the
sufficiency of the signatories and so certify. When found sufficient and
proper, the Clerk shall present the petition to the Council at its next regular
meeting.
Section 9.4. Council Procedure.
   Upon receiving a certified initiatory or referendary petition from the
Clerk, the Council shall within thirty (30) days either: a) Adopt the ordinance
if it is an initiatory petition; b) Repeal the ordinance if it be a referendary
petition; or c) Determine to submit the proposal to the electors in either
case.
Section 9.5. Submission to Electors.
   Should the Council decide to submit the proposal to the electors, it shall
be submitted at the next election held in the City for any other purpose or at
a special election if the Council should so decide. The result shall be
determined by a majority vote of the electors voting except in cases where
otherwise required by law.
Section 9.6. General Provisions.
   The certification by the Clerk of the sufficiency of a referendary petition
shall automatically suspend the ordinance in question pending repeal by the
Council or final determination by the electors as the case may be. An ordinance
adopted by the electorate through initiatory proceedings may not be amended or
repealed by the Council for a period of two (2) years and then only by the
affirmative vote of at least four (4) Council members. Should two (2) or more
ordinances adopted at the same election have conflicting provisions, the one
receiving the highest vote shall prevail.
ARTICLE X
LEGISLATION
Section 10.1. Prior Legislation.
   All valid ordinances of the City of Davison which are not inconsistent with
this Charter, and which are in full force and effect at the time of the
effective date of this Charter, shall continue in full force and effect until
repealed or amended. If any such ordinance provides for the appointment of any
officers or any members of any boards or commissions by the Council, such
officers or members of any boards or commissions shall, after the effective
date of this Charter, be appointed in accordance with the provisions of this
Charter.
   The zoning regulations in effect at the date of this Charter of the City of
Davison shall remain in full force and effect unless the Council shall lawfully
adopt other zoning regulations or ordinances.
   Those provisions of any effective ordinance which are inconsistent with this
Charter are hereby repealed.
Section 10.2. Official Actions.
   All official action of the Council shall be by ordinance, resolution, or
motion. Action by resolution or motion shall be limited to matters required or
permitted to be so done by this Charter or by State or Federal law or
pertaining to the internal affairs or concerns of the City government. All acts
carrying a penalty for the violation thereof shall be by ordinance. The Council
shall have the authority to establish penalties for violations of ordinances,
but no punishment for violation of any ordinance shall exceed a fine of $500.00
or imprisonment for ninety (90) days, or both, in the discretion of the court
as provided by State law.
Section 10.3. Ordinances.
   The style of all ordinances shall be, "The City of Davison ordains." No
ordinances shall be revised, altered, or amended by reference to its title
only, but the section or sections of the ordinance revised, altered, or amended
shall be re-enacted and published in full. An ordinance may be repealed by
reference to its number and title only. The effective date of any ordinance
shall be stated in the ordinance and shall be at least ten (10) days after its
adoption and publication unless the Council shall fix an earlier date upon
attaching a declaration of emergency affecting the public peace, health, or
safety. However, no measure making or amending a grant, renewal, or extension
of a franchise or other special privilege shall ever be passed as an emergency
measure, and no ordinance imposing a penalty shall take effect until at least
ten (10) days after publication.
   The Council may adopt any detailed technical regulations (e.g., building
code, electric wiring code, etc.) as a City ordinance by a reference to any
recognized official or unofficial standard code.
Section 10.4. Ordinance Record.
   All ordinances when enacted shall be recorded by the Clerk in a book called
The Ordinance Book, and it shall be the duty of the Mayor and the Clerk to
authenticate the recording by their official signatures.
Section 10.5. Zoning Ordinances Public Hearing Notice.
   In the case of a proposed zoning ordinance or proposed zoning ordinance
amendment, at least one (1) public hearing shall be held by the commission
appointed to recommend zoning regulations. Not less than fifteen (15) days
notice of the time and place of the public hearing shall first be published in
an official paper or a paper of general circulation in the City. The hearing
notice shall also contain either the text or a short summary of the regulatory
effect of the proposed ordinance or amendment.
Section 10.6. Publication of Notices; Proceedings and Ordinances.
   Notices of proceedings requiring publication and all ordinances, including
emergency ordinances, shall be published, before they become operative, once in
any newspaper generally circulated in the City or order such notices of
proceedings or ordinances printed and posted in at least five (5) public places
within the City, one of which shall be posted prominently at the usual place of
meeting of the Council. The Clerk shall enter in the Clerk's records
immediately after such publication a certificate of publication or posting
stating the date and the name of the newspaper in which such publication was
made or list of places where such postings were made. Such certificate shall be
evidence, if uncontested, of the due publication of such notice of proceedings
or ordinances. In addition, the certificate of publication of ordinances shall
be entered in The Ordinance Book in a designated blank space just following the
ordinance to which the certificate refers. The City Council shall by resolution
determine the number of copies of each ordinance to be available at cost for
public distribution.
Section 10.7. Compilation and Revision.
   If the Council shall by resolution order a revision and codification of City
ordinances, a number of copies of this as determined by the Council shall be
compiled in booklet form and available for a fee for public distribution. An
ordinance shall be adopted establishing such revised and codified ordinances
together with any amendments, additions, or deletions. Such codified ordinances
need not be recorded in The Ordinance Book.
ARTICLE XI
GENERAL FINANCE; BUDGET PROCEDURE
Section 11.1. Fiscal Year.
   The fiscal year of the City shall begin on July 1 and shall constitute the
budget year of the City government.
Section 11.2. System of Accounts.
   The City shall maintain a system of accounts that conforms to a uniform
system of accounts as required by law.
Section 11.3. Budget Procedure.
   Each City officer shall submit to the City Manager an itemized estimate of
the expenditures for the next fiscal year for the department or activities
under the officer's control on or before the second Monday in April of each
year. This estimate shall include reasons for all recommended increases and
decreases as compared with appropriations for the current fiscal year. The City
Manager shall prepare a complete itemized budget for the next fiscal year and
shall submit it to the Council on or before the second Monday in May of each
year.
Section 11.4. Budget Document.
   The budget document shall present a complete financial plan for the next
fiscal year. It shall include at least the following information:
      (a)   Detailed estimates of all proposed expenditures for each department
and office of the City, showing the expenditures for corresponding items for
the current and last preceding fiscal years.
      (b)   Statements of the bonded and other indebtedness of the City,
showing the debt redemption and interest requirements, the debt authorized and
unissued and the condition of sinking funds, if any.
      (c)   Detailed estimates of all anticipated income of the City from
sources other than taxes and borrowing, with a comparative statement of the
amounts received by the City from each of the same or similar sources for the
last preceding and current fiscal years.
      (d)   A statement of the estimated balance or deficit, as the case may
be, for the end of the current fiscal year.
      (e)   An estimate of the amount of money to be raised from current and
delinquent taxes and the amount to be raised from bond issues which together
with income from other sources will be necessary to meet the proposed
expenditures.
      (f)   Such other supporting schedules as the Council may deem necessary
or may require.
Section 11.5. Budget Hearing.
   A public hearing on the budget shall be held before its final adoption at
such time and place as the Council shall direct, and notice of such public
hearing shall be published at least one week in advance by the Clerk. A copy of
the proposed budget shall be on file and available to the public during office
hours at the office of the City Manager for a period of at least one week prior
to such public hearing.
Section 11.6. Adoption of Budget; Tax Limit.
   Not later than the first regularly scheduled meeting in June of each year,
the Council shall by resolution adopt the budget for the next fiscal year and
shall provide by resolution for a levy of the amount necessary to be raised by
taxation for Municipal purposes, which shall not exceed 1.485 percent of the
taxable valuation of all real and personal property in the City subject to
taxation. Included in the maximum levy for Municipal purposes of 1.485 percent
of the taxable valuation is .15 percent designated specifically for police
protection within the City and .135 percent designated specifically for
purposes of paying the costs of acquiring and constructing additions,
extensions and improvements to the City's Water Supply and Sewage Disposal
System; which .135 percent shall only be levied beginning with the fiscal year
beginning July 1, 2007 and ending with the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2026.
(Amended 11-4-03; 5-8-07)
Section 11.7. Transfer of Appropriations.
   After the budget has been adopted, no money shall be drawn from the Treasury
of the City nor shall any obligation for the expenditure of money be incurred
except in accordance with the budget appropriation. The Council may transfer
any unencumbered appropriation balance or any portion thereof from one
department fund or agency to another. The balance in any appropriation which
has not been encumbered at the end of the fiscal year shall revert to the
General Fund and be re-appropriated during the next fiscal year.
Section 11.8. Budget Control.
   As soon as it appears that income is less than anticipated, the Council
shall amend the general appropriations ordinance to keep expenditures within
the cash income as provided by State law. In any event, at the beginning of
each quarter during the fiscal year and more often if required by Council, the
City Manager shall submit data to the Council showing the relation between the
estimated and actual income and expenses to date. If the revenues should exceed
the amounts estimated in the budget, the Council may make supplemental
appropriations.
Section 11.9. Depository.
   The Council shall designate the depository or depositories for City funds
and shall provide for the regular deposit of all City moneys. The Council shall
provide for such security for City deposits as is authorized or permitted by
State law.
Section 11.10. Independent Audit.
   An independent audit shall be made of all accounts of the City government at
least annually and more frequently if deemed necessary by the Council. This
audit shall be made by qualified accountants experienced in municipal
accounting. The results of the audit shall be made public in a manner the
Council shall determine. An annual report of the City business shall be made
available to the public in a form that will disclose pertinent facts concerning
the activities and finance of the City government.
ARTICLE XII
GENERAL FINANCE; GENERAL TAXATION
Section 12.1. Subjects of Taxation.
   The subjects of taxation for municipal purposes shall be the same as for
State, County, and school purposes under State law except that there shall be
no City Income Tax.
Section 12.2. Taxation Procedure.
   City taxes shall be levied, collected, and returned in the manner provided
by State law except as otherwise provided by this Charter.
Section 12.3. Preparation of the Assessment Roll.
   The Assessor shall make and complete an assessment roll for the City, in the
manner and form provided in the general tax law of the State, not later than
the first Monday in March each year. On said date the Assessor shall file such
roll with the Clerk for public inspection during the normal office hours of the
Clerk, and such period of inspection shall continue until the date of convening
of the Board of Review. On that date the Clerk shall turn such assessment roll
over to the Board of Review. Further, the Assessor shall, by first class mail
addressed to the owner named on the tax roll, notify the owner of any change in
the assessment of the property; such notice shall be mailed prior to March 1.
Failure on the part of the Assessor to give such notice shall not invalidate
the assessment roll nor release the person or property assessed from any taxes
provided in this Charter.
Section 12.4. Meeting of the Board of Review.
   The Board of Review shall convene in its first session on the Tuesday
following the first Monday in March of each year, at such time of day and place
as shall be designated by the Council, and shall remain in session for at least
eight (8) hours for the purpose of reviewing and correcting the roll. If
necessary, said Board, on its own motion or on sufficient cause being shown by
any person, shall add to said roll the names of persons, the value of personal
property, and the description and value of real property liable to assessment
in said City, omitted from such assessment roll, and in the assessment and
valuation of the property thereon, and they shall cause to be done whatever
else may be necessary to make said roll comply with the provision of this
Charter.
   In each case in which the assessed value of any property is increased over
the amount shown on the assessment roll prepared by the Assessor, when any
property is added to such roll by the Board or when the Board has resolved to
consider at its second session such increasing of an assessment or the adding
of any property to such roll, the Assessor shall give notice thereof to the
owners as shown by said roll, by first class letter mailed not later than the
day following the end of the first session of the Board; and he shall file with
the Board sworn certification to such effect. Such notice shall state the date,
time, place and purpose of the second session of the Board. The failure to give
any such notice, or of the owner to receive it, shall not invalidate any
assessment roll or assessment thereon.
   The Board of Review shall convene in its second session on the second Monday
in March of each year, at such time of day and place as shall be designated by
the Council, and shall continue in session until all interested persons have
had an opportunity to be heard, but in no case for less than eight (8) hours.
At the end of the second session, the Board may not increase any assessment or
add any property to the rolls except in those cases in which the Board resolved
at its first session to consider such increase or addition at its second
session.
Section 12.5. Meeting; Notice of Meeting.
   Notice of the date, time and place of the meeting of the Board of Review
shall be published by the Clerk at least one week before the meeting by
publication in a generally circulated newspaper serving the area. The notice
shall appear in three successive issues of the newspaper where available;
otherwise, by the posting of the notice in five conspicuous places in the City.
Section 12.6. Endorsement of Assessment Roll.
   After the Board of Review has completed its review of the assessment roll,
and not later than the first Monday in April, the majority of its members shall
endorse thereon and sign a statement to the effect that the same is the
assessment roll of the City for the year in which it has been prepared. The
omission of such endorsement shall not affect the validity of such roll. The
roll, as prepared by the City Assessor, shall stand as approved and adopted as
the act of the Board of Review except when changed by a vote as herein
provided.
Section 12.7. Certify Tax Levy to Assessor.
   Within three (3) days after the adoption by the Council of the budget for
the next fiscal year, the Clerk shall certify to the Assessor the amount of the
tax levy fixed by the Council. The Assessor shall prepare the City Tax Roll by
rateably assessing each person and piece of property on the assessment roll
together with all special assessments as well as any other amounts which the
Council may require under authority of State law or this Charter or determine
to be assessed or reassessed against any property or person.
Section 12.8. City Treasurer to Collect.
   After extending the taxes on the assessment roll and certifying to the roll
in the manner required of assessing officers by State law, the Assessor shall
deliver on or before June 30 of each year such assessment roll to the Clerk
together with a copy of it. The Clerk shall forthwith annex the warrant to the
original roll directing and requiring the City Treasurer to collect from the
several persons named in the roll the several sums, or the total, opposite
their respective names. The taxes thus assessed shall become at once a debt to
the City from the persons to whom they are assessed, and the amount assessed
together with all applicable charges shall on July 1 of each year become a lien
on the property assessed of the same character and effect as the lien created
by general law for State and County taxes. The lien shall be discharged upon
payment.
Section 12.9. Taxes; When Due.
   City taxes shall be due and payable on July 1 of each year. All taxes paid
on or before August 31 of the same year shall be collected without additional
charge. From and after August 31, there shall be added one (1) percent per
month or fraction thereof, to taxes remaining unpaid, together with a
collection fee of three (3) percent.
Section 12.10. Return to County Treasurer.
   If any of the City taxes on real property on the City tax roll remain unpaid
on March 1 next following the date when the roll was received by the Treasurer,
then it shall be the duty of the City Treasurer to return all such unpaid taxes
on real property to the County Treasurer in the same manner as returns made by
township treasurers of State and County taxes. These returns shall be made on a
delinquent tax roll which the City Treasurer shall make in duplicate. This roll
shall include all the additional charges previously provided by this Charter.
The additional charges on the roll shall be added to the amount assessed
against each description in the roll. The taxes thus returned shall be
collected in the same manner as other taxes returned to the County Treasurer
are collected under the provisions of the general tax laws of the State, and
the same rate of interest and all charges shall be collected upon that real
property, and all taxes upon real property so returned as delinquent shall be
and remain a lien upon that real property until paid. The City Treasurer shall
retain the copy of the delinquent tax roll in the files of the City.
Section 12.11. State, County, School and Library Taxes.
   For the purpose of assessing and levying taxes in the City for State,
County, school, and library purposes, the City shall be considered the same as
a township. All provisions of State law relative to the collection of these
taxes, the accounting for these taxes to the appropriate taxing units, and the
returning of property for non-payment of these taxes shall be the
responsibility of the City Treasurer who shall perform the same duties and have
the same powers as township treasurers.
ARTICLE XIII
GENERAL FINANCE; BORROWING POWER
Section 13.1. General Borrowing.
   Subject to the applicable provisions of State law and this Charter, the
Council may authorize by proper ordinance or resolution the borrowing of money
for any purpose within the scope of the powers vested in the City and may issue
bonds of the City or other evidences of indebtedness for the borrowing and may
pledge the full faith, credit, and resources of the City for the payment of the
obligation created.
Section 13.2. Special Assessment Bonds.
   Subject to the applicable provisions of the general laws of the State, the
Council shall have authority to borrow money in anticipation of the payment of
special assessments or combination of special assessments made for the purpose
of defraying the cost of any public improvement and to issue bonds for the
borrowing. These special assessment bonds may be either an obligation of the
special assessment district or districts or both an obligation of the special
assessment district or districts and a general obligation of the City. All
collections on each special assessment roll or combination of rolls shall be
set apart in a separate fund for the payment of the principal and interest of
the bonds issued in anticipation of the payment of these special assessments
and shall be used for no other purpose.
Section 13.3. Mortgage Bonds.
   When the City is authorized to acquire, own, or operate any public utility,
it may in accordance with the provisions of the State Constitution, issue
mortgage bonds for the purpose beyond the general limit of bonded indebtedness
prescribed by the general laws of the State of Michigan provided that any
mortgage bonds issued beyond the general limit of bonded indebtedness
prescribed by law shall not impose any liability upon the City but shall be
secured only upon the property and revenues of the public utility, including a
franchise, as prescribed by State law.
Section 13.4. Other Bonds.
   The City shall have power to issue revenue or other types of bonds in the
manner and for the purpose permitted by the Constitution and general laws of
the State of Michigan.
Section 13.5. Preparation and Record.
   Each bond or other evidence of indebtedness shall contain on its face a
statement specifying the purpose for which it is issued and it shall be
unlawful for any officer of the City to use the proceeds from it for any other
purpose. Any officer who shall violate this provision shall be deemed guilty of
misconduct in office. All bonds and other evidences of indebtedness issued by
the City shall be signed by the actual or facsimile signatures of the officers
authorized by the City Council. A complete and detailed record of all bonds and
other evidences of indebtedness issued by the City shall be kept by the City
Treasurer. Upon the payment of any bond or other evidence of indebtedness, it
shall be marked "Canceled."
ARTICLE XIX
SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS
Section 14.1. Council Resolution.
   Whenever the Council shall determine that the whole or any part of the
expense of any public improvement shall be defrayed by special assessments upon
the property especially benefited, it shall so declare by resolution. The
resolution shall state the estimated cost of the improvement, what proportion
of the its cost shall be paid by special assessments, and what part, if any,
shall be paid from the general funds of the City. The resolution shall also
state the number of installments in which assessments may be paid and shall
designate the districts or land and premises upon which special assessments
shall be levied.
Section 14.2. Special Assessment Roll.
   Within twenty-one (21) days after the Council shall have determined by
resolution that the whole or any part of the expense of any public improvement
shall be defrayed by special assessments upon the property specifically
benefited, the City Assessor shall make an assessment roll of all lots and
parcels of land within the designated district benefited by the proposed
improvement.
Section 14.3. Review.
   The assessment roll shall be open to public inspection for a period of seven
(7) working days before the Council meets as a Board of Review to review the
roll and to hear complaints.
Section 14.4. Notice.
   Notice of the opening of the roll for public inspection and of the time and
place of the meeting of the Council, acting as the Board of Review, to hear
complaints shall be published by the Clerk at least one (1) week before the
opening of the roll for public inspection.
Section 14.5. Objections to Improvement.
   If the owners of more than one-half (1/2) of the property to be assessed
shall object in writing to the improvement at or prior to the meeting of the
Board of Review, the assessment shall not be made without a four-fifths (4/5)
vote of the members of the Council. Every special assessment roll ratified and
confirmed by the Council, acting as the Board of Review, shall be final and
conclusive except as may be subject to administrative or judicial appeal as
provided by State law.
Section 14.6. Additional Assessment; Refunds.
   When any special assessment roll shall prove insufficient to meet the costs
of the improvement for which it was made, the Council may make an additional
proportional assessment. Should the assessment prove larger than necessary by
five (5) percent or less, the Council may place the excess in the City
Treasury. If the assessment prove larger than necessary by more than five (5)
percent, the excess shall be proportionally refunded according to assessments.
Section 14.7. Liens and Collection.
   There shall be a lien upon the property assessed for all special assessments
and for all interest and charges upon the property from the date of
confirmation of the roll. This lien shall remain until all special assessments
are paid and shall be of the same character and effect as a lien created by
general law for State and County taxes. Interest at a rate not to exceed six
(6) percent per annum shall be collected on deferred installments of special
assessments. From a date after confirmation fixed by the Council, the same
penalties and collection fee shall be required on delinquent installments of
any special assessments as are provided by this Charter to be paid on
delinquent general City taxes. Any delinquent special assessments shall be
returned to the County Treasurer for collection and shall be handled in the
same manner as are delinquent general City taxes, except, no delinquent special
assessments nor any delinquent installment of the special assessments shall be
returned to the County Treasurer for collection unless the delinquency has
continued for a period of six (6) months and then not until March 1 next.
Section 14.8. Procedure.
   To make effective the provisions of this Charter, the assessment procedure
outlined in State law concerning plans and specifications, estimate of costs,
notice and hearing, the making of the assessment roll and correction of errors,
the collection of special assessments, and any other matters concerning the
making of improvements by the special assessment method which are not
inconsistent with the provisions of this Charter are adopted into this Charter.
All acts required in the cited State laws to be performed by a Board of Special
Assessors shall be performed by the Assessor.
ARTICLE XV
Section 15.1. General Powers Respecting Utilities.
   The City shall not acquire any public utility furnishing light, heat or
power, or grant any public utility franchise which is not subject to revocation
at the will of the City, unless the proposition shall first have been approved
by three-fifths (3/5) of the electors voting thereon. The City may not sell any
public utility unless the proposition shall first have been approved by a
majority of the electors voting thereon.
Section 15.2. Appropriation of Private Property.
   Private property may be taken, appropriated, and held, either within or
without the City, for any public use in connection with any acquisition,
enlargement, or extension of public utilities for supplying water, light, heat,
electrical power, gas, sewage, and garbage disposal facilities, or any of them;
for the purpose of opening, widening, altering or extending streets, alleys,
and avenues; for the construction of bridges, public buildings, and other
public structures; for public grounds, parking spaces, parks, market places and
spaces; for the improvement of waters and watercourses within the City; for
sewers, drains, and ditches; for public medical facilities, and public
cemeteries; and for other lawful and necessary public uses. The ownership of
such property shall be acquired by the City by negotiation and purchase or in
any other manner permitted by the general laws of the State for the taking of
private property for public use.
Section 15.3. Control of Utilities.
   The Council may enact ordinances and adopt resolutions as may be necessary
for carrying into effect the powers conferred upon the City by the provisions
of this Charter and for the care, protection, preservation, control, and
operation of any public utilities which the City may acquire, own or operate
including all fixtures, appurtenances, apparatus, buildings, and machinery
connected or belonging to any of these.
Section 15.4. Improvements.
   In case the Council shall declare that it is expedient to construct,
improve, enlarge, extend, or repair any public utility for the purpose of
supplying sewer, light, heat, or electrical power, securing an adequate supply
of water, or any other utility service, the cost of which must be met by bond
issues or loans, then the Council shall have made and recorded in its
proceedings an estimate of the expenses thereof. After an estimate has been
obtained, the question of improving or extending the present plants or
acquiring or constructing new plants, with the amount of the estimate plainly
stated, shall be submitted to the qualified electors of the City, and if a
majority of the qualified electors voting in the election approve the question,
the City may proceed with the improvement, etc. If the cost of the improvement,
etc. exceeds, or it can reasonably be determined after the improvement, etc. is
started that it will exceed, the estimate of expenses, then, except as
otherwise permitted by the Constitution or general laws of the State, the
question of increasing the amount authorized for any such improvement, etc.
shall be submitted to the qualified electors of the City at its next regular
election or at a special election called for that purpose by the Council in the
manner provided in this Charter. The question will have been carried if three-
fifths (3/5) of the qualified electors voting in the election shall have voted
in favor of the question.
   The Council may authorize construction of any improvements and extensions to
existing plants as the normal growth of the plants may require if the cost of
such improvements and extensions can be met by the expenditure of any
accumulated surplus. No extensions or improvements in excess of this amount
shall be made except by reference to the electors as required by this Charter.
Section 15.5. Rates.
   The Council shall have the power to fix from time to time such just and
equitable rates as may be deemed advisable for supplying the inhabitants of the
City and others with water, light, heat, electric power, and with such other
utility services as the City may acquire. The Council may authorize a
reasonable payment in lieu of taxes, from any utility to the General Fund, so
as to reimburse the General Fund for services that the City provided to that
utility.
Section 15.6. Utility Charges; Collection.
   The Council shall provide by ordinance for the collection of all public
utility charges made by the City. When any person or persons or any firm or
corporation shall fail or refuse to pay to the City any sums due on utility
bills which are not covered by deposits, the utility service or services upon
which such delinquency exists may be shut off or discontinued and suit may be
instituted by the City for the collection of the delinquency in any court of
competent jurisdiction.
Section 15.7. Accounts.
   Separate accounts shall be kept for each public utility owned or operated by
the City, distinct from other City accounts, and in a manner showing the true
and complete financial result of City ownership or operation, or both,
including all assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses. These accounts shall
show the actual cost to the City of each public utility, the cost of all
extensions, additions and improvements, all expenses of maintenance, the
amounts set aside for sinking fund purposes, and all operating expenses of
every description. They shall show as nearly as possible the value of any
service furnished to or rendered by any public utility by or to any other City
department. They shall also show a proper allowance for depreciation and
insurance. The Council shall annually have printed for public distribution a
report showing the financial results of City ownership or operation or both.
The report shall give for each utility the information specified in this
section and any further information the Council may require.
Section 15.8. Disposal of Plants.
   The City shall not sell, exchange, lease, or in any way transfer or dispose
of its property, easements, income, equipment, privilege or asset belonging to
or appertaining to any utility which it may acquire unless and except the
proposition shall first have been submitted, at a special election held for the
purpose in the manner provided in this Charter, to the qualified voters of the
City and approved by them by a three-fifths (3/5) majority vote of the electors
voting thereon. All contracts, negotiations, grants, leases, or other forms of
transfer in violation of this section shall be void and of no effect as against
the City. The provisions of this section shall not, however, apply to the sale
or exchange of any articles or equipment of any City owned utility that are
worn out or useless, or which could, with advantage to the service, be replaced
by new and improved machinery or equipment.
ARTICLE XVI
FRANCHISES; CONTRACTS; PERMITS
Section 16.1. General.
   The City Council shall have the right to enter into any contract permitted
by the laws of the State of Michigan or as authorized by the City Charter.
Section 16.2. Public Utility Franchises.
   All irrevocable public utility franchises and all renewals, extensions, and
amendments or any repeal of them shall be granted only by ordinance. No
ordinance for these purposes shall be adopted before thirty (30) days after
application for a franchise, renewal, extension, or amendment has been filed
with the Council nor until a full public hearing has been held on it. No such
ordinance shall become effective until it has been submitted to the electors
and has been approved by three-fifths (3/5) of the electors voting upon it. No
such ordinance shall be submitted to the electors at an election unless sixty
(60) days shall have passed after the grantee named in it has filed its
unconditional acceptance of all of the terms of such franchise, and it shall
not be submitted to a special election unless the expense of holding the
election, as determined by the Council, shall have been paid to the City
Treasurer by the grantee. No exclusive franchises shall ever be granted, and no
franchise shall be granted for a longer term than thirty (30) years. No such
franchise shall be directly or indirectly transferable except with the approval
of the Council expressed by ordinance.
Section 16.3. Right of Regulation.
   All public utility franchises shall be subject to the right of the City:
      (a)   To repeal the ordinance for misuse or non-use or for failure to
comply with the provisions of the granting ordinance;
      (b)   To require proper and adequate extension of facilities and services
and their maintenance at the highest practicable standard of efficiency;
      (c)   To establish reasonable standards of service and quality of
products and prevent unlawful or unjust discrimination in service or rates;
      (d)   To make independent audit and examination of accounts at any time
and to require reports annually;
      (e)   To require continuous and uninterrupted service to the public
throughout the entire period of the franchise in accordance with the terms of
the franchise;
      (f)   To impose other regulations as may be determined by the Council to
be conducive to safety, welfare, and accommodation of the public.
Section 16.4. Regulation of Rates.
   Where permitted by law or regulation, all public utility franchises shall,
after a public hearing, make provision for fixing rates, fares, and charges and
for readjustments of them at periodic intervals of not more than five (5) years
or less that one (1) year, either by arbitration upon terms to be specifically
set forth in the franchise, or by any state agency, or at the election of the
City. The value of the property of the utility used as a basis for fixing such
rates, fares, and charges shall never include a value predicated upon the
franchise, goodwill, or prospective profits.
Section 16.5. Purchase; Condemnation.
   The City shall have the right to acquire by condemnation or otherwise the
property of any public utility in accordance with State and Federal laws
provided that the price to be paid shall never include any value predicated
upon the franchise, goodwill, or prospective profits.
Section 16.6. Revocable Permits.
   Temporary permits for public utilities, revocable at any time at the will of
the Council, may be granted by the Council by resolution on such terms and
conditions as it shall determine. These permits shall never be construed to be
franchises or amendments to franchises.
Section 16.7. Use of Streets by Utilities.
   Every public utility franchise shall be subject to the right of the City to
use, control, and regulate the use of its streets, alleys, bridges, and public
places and the space above and beneath them. Every public utility shall pay the
part of the cost of improvement or maintenance of streets, alleys, bridges,
watercourses, and public places as shall arise from their use, and every public
utility shall protect, defend, and save the City harmless from all damages
arising from use of the utility. Every public utility may be required by the
City to permit joint use of its property and appurtenances located in the
streets, alleys, and public places of the City by the City and other utilities
in so far as this joint use may be reasonably practicable and upon payment of
reasonable rental for the use. When an application is made by any public
utility for joint use and full agreement on terms and conditions cannot be
reached, the Council shall provide for arbitration of the terms and conditions
of this joint use and the compensation to be paid for it, and the award shall
be final.
Section 16.8. Contracts for City Improvements.
   The costs of all City improvements and the contracts for these improvements
shall be governed by a purchasing ordinance which provides for limitations on
spending by the City Manager without prior approval of the Council and spending
by the Council without the necessity of formal bidding as made and provided by
the Council.
ARTICLE XVII
STREETS AND ALLEYS; WATERS AND WATERCOURSES
Section 17.1. Streets.
   The right to use, and to control and regulate the use of its streets,
alleys, bridges and public places, and the space above and beneath them is
reserved to the City.
Section 17.2. Water and Watercourses.
   The City shall have the power to use, control, and regulate the use of all
